title: Choledocholithiasis Case
diagnosis_topic: Common bile duct stones causing biliary obstruction without infection
setup_script: A 50-year-old woman presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. She has a prior history of gallstones but no prior surgeries. On exam, she is mildly icteric but otherwise stable. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.2 °C.
Labs show total bilirubin 3.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 250 U/L, AST/ALT mildly elevated, amylase normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders right upper quadrant ultrasound
dynamic_flow.reply: Ultrasound reveals gallbladder with stones, common bile duct measuring 9 mm, but no definite stone visualized.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests MRCP or EUS
dynamic_flow.reply: MRCP/EUS demonstrates a 6 mm stone in the distal common bile duct causing obstruction.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV fluids and analgesia
dynamic_flow.reply: The patient has symptomatic relief while awaiting intervention.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults gastroenterology for ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: ERCP with endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone extraction is performed successfully.
The patient develops fever and hypotension concerning for cholangitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident plans interval laparoscopic cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Cholecystectomy is scheduled within a few days of ERCP to prevent recurrence.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident misdiagnoses as simple cholelithiasis and proceeds with cholecystectomy without addressing CBD stone
dynamic_flow.reply: Postoperatively, the patient remains jaundiced with worsening labs, concerning for retained stones.
Intraoperative cholangiography demonstrates no residual stones and confirms biliary anatomy.
The patient is monitored; liver enzymes normalize over the next few days.
The patient expresses understanding of the need for cholecystectomy completion and signs of recurrence.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your operative steps for laparoscopic cholecystectomy in this patient.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of choledocholithiasis using labs and imaging
Role of MRCP/EUS and ERCP in diagnosis and therapy
Timing of ERCP relative to cholecystectomy
Recognition of complications if stones are untreated
Use of intraoperative cholangiography and postoperative patient education
Ability to clearly describe operative technique for laparoscopic cholecystectomy

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning in recognizing choledocholithiasis and selecting appropriate diagnostic imaging. Your sequencing of ERCP followed by cholecystectomy showed good clinical judgment. Communication of your management plan was clear and structured. Areas for Improvement: Earlier articulation of the risks of delayed ERCP and potential complications would improve your performance. Additionally, expanding on the role of intraoperative cholangiography in preventing retained stones and providing a complete, stepwise description of laparoscopic cholecystectomy technique would strengthen your surgical knowledge. Suggested Reading Topics: - SCORE: Choledocholithiasis and Gallstone Disease - ACS/ASE Review: Management of Common Bile Duct Stones - Indications and Technique for Intraoperative Cholangiography - Stepwise Approach to Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
